Award.AwardTitle: Cal Poly Science Noyce Scholars Program, Phase I

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo (Cal Poly) in partnership with three local school districts (Santa Maria Bonita School District (SMBSD), Santa Maria Joint Union High School District (SMJUHSD), Lucia Mar Unified School District (LMUSD) is supporting 30 Noyce Scholars recruited from the large pool of science and engineering undergraduates at Cal Poly. The Cal Poly Science Noyce Scholars program is collaborating with a Noyce Scholars program in Mathematics at Cal Poly, adding value to the experience for both math and science Noyce Scholars and creating a community of Noyce Scholars at Cal Poly focused on issues related to teaching in high-need school districts. The Scholars are mentored by university faculty and experienced classroom teachers to prepare them for success in teaching in high-need school district settings. The project is also promoting the creation of undergraduate cohorts of Noyce Scholars who prepare for teaching much sooner in their academic careers by tutoring students, helping to teach inquiry-based modules in science classrooms, and helping students with science fair projects. The broader impact of this program is that Science Noyce Scholars leave Cal Poly to teach throughout the state of California strongly committed and better prepared to serving as science teachers in high-need school districts. Noyce Scholars serve as role models and educational leaders who ultimately encourage many of their own students to pursue degrees and careers in STEM disciplines. Noyce Scholars from this program motivate and recruit students from within high-need districts to become the next generation of Noyce Scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of the Cal Poly Science Phase I Noyce Program involved a) recruiting four cohorts of highly qualified science and engineering students into teaching in high need school districts and b) further enhancing the level of scholarship and educational experience for students enrolled in the Cal Poly credential program with an emphasis on teaching in high-need school districts. Over the course of the grant, the project successfully awarded 53 scholarships to 35 highly qualified science and engineering undergraduates and credential candidates. Of these, 20 received scholarship funding for one year, 12 were funded for two years, and 3 were funded for three years. Each Noyce Scholar committed to teaching for at least two years in a high-need district for each year of scholarship funding received.

The attached figure shows the transition of these Cal Poly Science Noyce Scholars from undergraduates and credential candidates (blue) to full time credentialed teachers (green). As of Fall 2014, 33 were currently teaching, one was still seeking a teaching position, and was still completing a credential. Of those teaching, 15 had already fulfilled their Noyce teaching commitments and 18 were in the process of fulfilling their teaching commitments. Importantly, of those who had completed the Noyce teaching commitment by Fall 2014, all were continuing to teach, and all but one were still working in high-need districts.

Featured elements of the project included monthly Noyce Seminars that brought Noyce Scholars together around topics related to teaching science in high-need settings. The project also hosted an annual Noyce Narrative event that brought Noyce alumni back to Cal Poly to describe their classroom experiences. The project promoted pre-service participation in professional development conferences (e.g., California Science Teachers Association Conferences and National and Western Regional Noyce Conferences) and summer teacher training workshops (e.g., Modeling Instruction). The Cal Poly Science Phase I Noyce Scholars Program also promoted participation in research experience as part of teacher preparation. In total, 14 of the 35 Noyce Scholars (37%) participated in the California State University STEM Teacher and Researcher Program (STAR), which provides paid summer research fellowships at national research laboratories to pre-service and early career teachers (www.StarTeacherResearcher.org).

Another emphasis of the project has been providing opportunities to strengthen connections and support among Noyce Scholars from campuses across the country. Over the lifetime of the grant, the project directly supported 81 Scholars from 35 Noyce campuses in 17 states to participate in the STAR Program. The project also hosted the 2011 NASA-Noyce Summer Inquiry Institute, a weeklong professional development workshop coordinated in partnership with scientists and educators from NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory that brought together 22 Scholars from 15 Noyce Programs in 10 states.

The intellectual merit of the Cal Poly Phase I Noyce Program has been grounded in the recruitment of exceptional science and engineering majors into a quality science teacher preparation program with an enhanced emphasis on teaching in high-need settings. The project promoted the creation of four undergraduate cohorts of Noyce Scholars who began preparing for teaching in high-need settings much earlier in their academic careers. These scholars were mentored by university faculty members and experienced classroom teachers-in-residence to prepare them for success in teaching in high-need settings.
